text: in that one it has a live insects on it
my name is Michel tunic I am a research
chemist for the US Department of
Agriculture and I wrote a book called
the science of cheese the only cheese
that I really wouldn't want to eat is
this causa Marzu which is from sardinia
and in that one it has a live insects on
it and what they generally do is either
scrape off the insects before you eat it
or they put the cheese in a paper bag
and you can hear the insect popping
around off the inside of the bag and you
wait until that noise dies down meaning
that the insects have basically died and
then you open it up and then you eat it
well a lot of traditional cheeses have
bugs growing on them you know cheese
skippers and cheese mites and things
like that and some of that even
contributes to the texture and the
flavor of the cheese nowadays that's not
the kind of thing that consumers want to
have so if they see cheese with insects
growing on if they were want to scrape
those insects often get rid of the
cheese but there are some people's
untraditional especially in Europe who
certainly don't mind eating cheese that
has some insects on it it is not really
legal to sell that cheese in Sardinia
for that reason if they don't think it's
good enough health-wise to sell and I
don't think it's good enough to eat
you
